statement.text: Imaging of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) utilizes multiple modalities: ultrasound (US) for screening and surveillance, CT angiography (CTA) for preoperative planning and anatomic characterization, and MR angiography (MRA) as an alternative when contrast nephrotoxicity is a concern.
statement.formal: AAA Imaging Modalities: US (screening, surveillance), CTA (gold standard for planning), MRA (alternative for contrast-sensitive patients)

explanation.intuition: Think of imaging AAA like photographing a bulging balloon from different angles. Ultrasound gives a quick, real-time view without radiation - perfect for regular checkups. CT with contrast provides detailed 3D images showing exactly how the aneurysm relates to other blood vessels - essential for surgical planning. MRI offers similar detail but without iodinated contrast, useful when kidney function is impaired.
explanation.key_insight: The choice of imaging modality depends on clinical context: ultrasound for screening and surveillance of small AAAs, CTA for symptomatic or large AAAs requiring intervention planning. Accurate sizing requires outer-wall-to-outer-wall measurement perpendicular to the flow lumen.
explanation.technical_details: Ultrasound sensitivity for AAA detection is >95% with specificity approaching 100%. CTA provides sub-millimeter resolution with multiplanar reconstructions and centerline measurements. Key anatomic features to assess include: neck length (distance from lowest renal artery to aneurysm), neck diameter, neck angle, iliac artery diameter and tortuosity, presence of thrombus, and accessory renal arteries.
common_misconceptions: All AAAs need CT - small aneurysms can be monitored with ultrasound alone
Any size measurement technique is acceptable - standardized protocols are essential
Contrast is always needed - non-contrast CT can detect AAA but misses branch vessel detail
MRA is inferior to CTA - MRA provides comparable accuracy for most planning purposes

ultrasound.measurement: Anteroposterior (AP) diameter outer-wall-to-outer-wall, perpendicular to flow

ct_angiography.protocol: Thin-slice acquisition (≤1mm), arterial phase timing, multiplanar reformats, centerline analysis

definitions_glossary.neck: Segment of normal aorta between lowest renal artery and proximal extent of aneurysm
definitions_glossary.centerline: Path following the center of the aortic lumen, used for accurate length measurements
definitions_glossary.mural_thrombus: Clot lining the inner wall of aneurysm, not included in diameter measurement
definitions_glossary.multiplanar_reconstruction: 3D CT data reformatted into different viewing planes

key_measurements.neck_length: Lowest renal artery to proximal aneurysm extent (minimum 10-15mm for standard EVAR)
key_measurements.neck_angle: Angle between suprarenal and infrarenal aorta (>60° complicates EVAR)
key_measurements.iliac_access: External iliac diameter and tortuosity for device delivery

definition.@value: Diagnostic imaging modalities used to detect, measure, and plan treatment for abdominal aortic aneurysm

learning_objectives: Select appropriate imaging modality for AAA evaluation
Identify key anatomic measurements for EVAR planning
Understand surveillance intervals based on AAA size
clinical_pearls: Ultrasound and CTA may measure differently - use same modality for longitudinal comparison
Mural thrombus should NOT be subtracted from diameter - measure outer wall
Neck angle >60° and neck length <10mm are relative contraindications to standard EVAR
Always check for iliac aneurysms and accessory renal arteries
